metadata.title: Nano silver embedded starch hybrid graphene oxide sandwiched poly(ethylmethacrylate) for packaging application

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano-Structures &Nano-Objects
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/nanoso
Nano silver embedded starch hybrid graphene oxide sandwiched poly(ethylmethacrylate) for packaging application Fanismita Mohanty, Sarat K. Swain ∗ Department of Chemistry, Veer Surendra Sai University of Technology, Burla, Sambalpur 768018, India
h i g h l i g h t s
• The thermal stability of nanocomposite increases with a remaining residue of 24%. • The oxygen barrier property is increased by 40% starch/GO/Ag2wt%. • The chemical resistance properties have also increased. • The biodegradability of nanocomposites is 4.5% after 180 days.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 4 September 2018 Received in revised form 5 March 2019 Accepted 28 March 2019
Keywords: Packaging Oxygen barrier Biopolymer Antimicrobial
a b s t r a c t
Herein, nano silver decorated starch hybrid poly(ethymethacrylate) (PEMA) nanobiocomposites are prepared by in situ polymerization technique. Electron microscopic studies are done in order to determine the morphology of nanobiocomposites. Spectroscopical investigations of the synthesized PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites are done in order to confirm the formation of nanobiocomposites. The existence of intermolecular hydrogen bonding in PEMA-co-starch is confirmed from Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) plot. The biodegradability, thermal stability, oxygen barrier properties, chemical resistance and antimicrobial properties of nanobiocomposites are enhanced significantly due to the proper dispersion of graphene oxide (GO) and AgNPs in PEMA-co-starch. The degradation temperature of material increases with a remaining residue of 24% after 800 oC. The oxygen barrier property is increased by 40% in PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag2wt% than that of copolymer. The tensile strength value has shown significant improvement from 0.5wt% to 1wt% of AgNPs loading. The biodegradability of nanobiocomposites is 4.5% after 180 days. The diameter of inhibition zone PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag2wt% towards Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus subtilis, Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli are 23mm, 18mm, 19mm and 24mm respectively. The thermally stable nanobiocomposites with high barrier properties, biodegradability and antimicrobial behavior are suitable for packaging industry.
© 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: fanismita2013@gmail.com (F. Mohanty), skswain_chem@vssut.ac.in, swainsk2@yahoo.co.in (S.K. Swain).

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The cost effectiveness, versatility and easy processibility have made polymeric materials widely useful [1–4]. Polymeric materials have been used in various fields like sensing, uv-blocking material, energy harvesting material, biomedical sector along with
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoso.2019.100300 2352-507X/© 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
for packaging industries [5–8]. In packaging sector, the nonbiodegradable post packaging wastes of polymeric materials are creating the prime environmental concern [9]. For this purpose, blending of commodity polymers (polypropylene and polyethylene etc.) with natural polymers (such as chitosan and starch) is one of way for improving the biodegradability and biocompatibility of synthetic polymer) [10,11]. The improvement of biodegradability has made the polymeric blend economically and ecological more compatible than pure synthetic polymer [12]. Emphasis is given for the recycling of thermoplast materials. The recycling of polypropylene and polyethylene based materials is helpful for reduction in raw waste materials, their shelf life and energy consumption [13,14]. In order to avoid these problems attention is given on biopolymer based packaging materials due to their wide availability, renewability, biodegradability and easy processability. To obtain better packaging quality along with biodegradability and biocompatible blends of biopolymers with other conventional polymers are prepared. Starch consists of two sub units (i.e. linear amylase and branched amylopectin) [15]. Thermoplastic starch (TPS) can be prepared by disruption of starch granules with glycerol [16–18]. The physical and chemical properties and morphological structure of the blends containing TPS depends upon concentration of TPS, glycerol content and processing conditions of synthetic polymer in blends [19]. Different processing techniques are employed for the preparation of starch/low density polyethylene (LDPE) blends by Huang et al. [20] The prepared blend has shown acceptable biodegradability (65wt% of weight loss in 2 weeks) and mechanical properties but has lifecycle. According to recycling study of poly (lactic acid)/polystyrene blends, the viscosity decreases after reprocessing and also the reprocessed blend have shown less strain at break and stress at break after processing (2 cycle of processing) [21]. The reduction in rheological and mechanical properties is observed after five extrusion processes [22]. The maintenance of material properties is only possible for polyethylene [23]. The improvement in biodegradability along with high level retention in blend properties are observed for starch/polyethylene blends after recycling [24]. Moreover, the starch is used in the present study for better binding of the as prepared nanocomposites for better processability. The antibacterial properties of the composites are achieved with incorporation of silver. The environmental demand of these blends decreases due to the reduction of properties after recycling.
There are certain primary characteristics of food packaging material. Retention of quality and safety of food are very essential. For this the food packaging material should have high mechanical stability, chemical stability and thermal stability along with excellent barrier property towards different gases and vapor (O2, CO2 and H2O), aroma barrier property, biodegradability, antimicrobial property and also offers safety to light and other external forces [25–31]. In other word food packaging material is nothing but a protective container for packaged food.
Various basic packaging materials of different physical structure and chemical nature have been used by human beings. Research have been carried out to improve the packaging property of these materials. Plastic packaging materials are preferable because of easy processability, low price, excellent physical and chemical property. Nearly 40% of plastic packaging materials are used for packaging of food [32]. The main problem of plastic packaging material is imperishability in environment. Upon burning these materials produces toxic gases. Persistency of post packaging waste is the main concern about plastic packaging material. Attention has been given for development of biodegradable packaging material. These polymers have renewable biological resources, excellent mechanical and barrier properties. The biodegradability, biocompatibility and renewability of biopolymers have made them suitable alternative for non-renewable and
non-biodegradable packaging materials. The addition of various additives such as antioxidants, antimicrobial agents, antifungal agents, colors and other nutrients can be easily added to biopolymers [33–35]. The shelf life of product considerably enhanced due to the use of packaging material. The longevity of products increases due to formation of suitable environment and physiochemical conditions by packaging material. Proper packaging system provides suitable mechanical properties, water vapor and gas barrier properties and also provides essential physiochemical and biological conditions for the packaged material [36].
The copolymerization of ethylmethacrylate with starch will provide biodegradability to the nanobiocomposites. The layered nanofiller GO will helpful in enhancing strength and mechanical properties of nanobiocomposites. The cytocompatibility of GO is also reported [37]. Reports are also available regarding the antimicrobial properties of GO [38]. AgNPs will provide antimicrobial properties to the nanobiocomposites which will helpful in increasing the shelf life of product. The thermoplastic polymer poly (ethyl methacrylate) (PEMA) has excellent thermal, mechanical, and chemical resistance properties. PEMA is principally used shatter-resistant material (resistant to light). It is low price and easy processability have made it suitable raw material for industrial sector [39]. Superabsorbent material [40], thermal energy storage [41] drug releasing material [41], storage of thermal energy [39] are the fields where PEMA has used as a component. PEMA is also reported to be used as a component of packaging material for barrier and heat resistance material [42]. The use of poly (methyl methacrylate) and alkylmethacrylates for medical device packaging due to its biocompatibility is also reported in literature [43]. Reports are also available for the use of PEMA in multilayer barrier packaging in order to provide high barrier capacity [44]. Poly (ethyl methacrylate) is a copolymer of ethylene whose application in packaging sector is reported [45]. The high chemical resistance, thermal and mechanical properties and the various applications as cited above are the criteria for choosing PEMA as a suitable material for matrix. For this PEMA is selected as the matrix for our present study. In situ incorporation of starch into EMA Although, the PEMA based composites are prepared with reinforcement of different fillers but the dispersion of reduced graphene oxide with PEMA is new in the literature. AgNPs are also chosen due to their effective antimicrobial activity against wide range of microbes and also provide antimicrobial protection for long duration in comparison to other biocides such as tetracycline and benzyl penicillin etc. Some bacteria have antibiotic resistance naturally and it develops due to the prolong use of antibiotics in other cases. For instance, Staphylococcus aureus and Neisseria gonorrhoeae have resistance to benzyl penicillin. Thus AgNPs are potential antimicrobial material against various types of bacteria, viruses and fungi [46]. Although the bactericidal action of AgNPs is not clear, the proposed mechanism suggests the bactericidal effect is due to electrostatic attraction between positive charged silver ion and negative charged cell membrane of microbes which leads to rupture of bacterial cell membrane. Ag+ ion also have strong affinity for thiol group of important enzymes required for DNA replication. Thus DNA replication stops causing bacterial death [47,48]. The prepared nanobiocomposites have application in packaging industry for providing antimicrobial protection, high gas barrier and thermal resistance properties along with biodegradation.
In the present manuscript, attempt has taken for the synthesis of biodegradable–antimicrobial packaging material. The thermal stability of the nanobiocomposites are considerably enhanced. The oxygen barrier property is increased by 40% in PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag2wt% than that of copolymer. The tensile strength value has shown significant improvement from 0.5wt% to 1wt% of AgNPs loading. The biodegradability of nanobiocomposites is
4.5% after 180 days. The diameter of inhibition zone PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag2wt% towards Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Bacillus subtilis, Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli are 23 mm, 18 mm, 19 mm and 24 mm respectively. The thermally stable nanobiocomposites with high barrier properties, biodegradability and antimicrobial behavior are suitable for packaging industry.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Ethyl methacrylate (EMA) monomer from Merck, Germany was used for experimental purpose. The EMA was washed with H3PO4 and NaOH solutions respectively for purification. Then the EMA was further purified by washing two times with double distilled water. Graphite powder from Merck, Germany was purchased which was used as the raw material for the preparation of GO. Modified Hummer’s process was used for the synthesis of GO [49]. The whole experimental procedure was carried out using double distilled water. Potassium persulphate (KPS) was the initiator for the polymerization reaction. Polymerization process was terminated with the help of ferrous ammonium sulfate. Silver nitrate from Sigma-Aldrich of 99.8% purity was used for synthesis of silver nanoparticles. Ascorbic acid of 99.5% purity was purchased from Fluka.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Preparation of AgNPs
sections.text:
AgNPs are prepared from silver nitrate using ascorbic acid
as reducing agent and starch as stabilizing agent. Ascorbic acid 0.01 mol/dm3 and 2% starch were added and diluted to 50 cm3. Then required amount of AgNO3 is dissolve in 5 cm3 of deionized water. Then the ascorbic acid–starch solution was stirred and AgNO3 solution was added at this state. After four hours the formation of AgNPs was indicated from brown color [50]. According to this procedure different molar (1.46 mM, 2.92 mM, 4.38 mM & 5.84 mM) AgNPs solutions were prepared.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Preparation of nanobiocomposites
sections.text:
The copolymer PEMA-co-Starch was synthesized with the
incorporation various percentage of starch. PEMA-co-Starch with 5wt% loading was taken depending upon the compatibility starch with PEMA. The compatibility of GO with PEMA was also studied. 2wt% of GO was found to be suitable. Then 3 ml of ethyl methacrylate and soluble starch solution was stirred in a three naked flask in nitrogen atmosphere at 30 ◦C. Then required amount of dispersed GO and 1.446 mM AgNPs were injected into it and temperature was raised to 55 ◦C and stirred for 30 min. 2 mL of 0.1 M potassium persulfate was injected at this stage and stirred for three hours. The formation of PEMA-co-Starch/GO/Ag .5wt% nanobiocomposites was indicated from the formation of light golden brown color suspension. Finally, 1 mL of ammonium ferrous sulfate [(NH4)2Fe(SO4)2.6H2O] was added to arrest the polymerization process. Similarly, 2.92 mM, 4.38 mM & 5.84 mM solutions were taken for the synthesis of PEMA-co-starch/GO/ Ag1wt%, PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag1.5wt% & PEMA-co-starch/GO/ Ag2wt% nanobiocomposites respectively. The schematic diagram of synthesis of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites is shown in Scheme 1.

sections.heading: 3. Characterization techniques
sections.text:
Japan based Shimadzu UV–visible spectrophotometer (model UV-2450) was used to confirm the formation of AgNPs. Rikagu X-ray diffractometer of model No. DD966 having its operation condition at 40 kV, 150 mA and CuKα (1.54◦ A) was used to record the X-ray diffraction patterns of AgNPs, PEMA-costarch, PEMA-co-starch/GO and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of starch, GO, PEMA-co-starch, PEMA-co-starch/GO, PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag.5wt% and PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag2wt% were taken with the help of FTIR spectrophotometer (Shimazdu, Japan,) with operating range 4000 cm−1 to 400 cm−1. Morphological analysis of copolymer as well as composite was studied with the help of scanning electron microscope (SEM) of model JEOL-JSM-5800. The dispersion of graphene oxide and Ag NPs in the PEMA-co-starch matrix was studied using Tecnai 12, Phillips transmission electron microscope (TEM) operating at 120 kV. The dispersed solution was sonicated and it was allowed to settle the heavier particles at bottom part of the test tube. The drop of the dispersed liquid was mounted in a copper grid of 300 mesh.
The thermal stability of prepared composites was measured by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) apparatus of Shimadzu Corporation, Japan having model DTG-60. It was done by heating the sample under nitrogen purge with a continuous heat supply of 10 degree/min. The chemical resistance of bionanobiocomposites was tested against dilute sodium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid. The oxygen barrier property of the nanobiocomposites was determined using an oxygen permeation analyzer, PMI instrument, Texas, NY, USA of model GP-201-A (ASTM F 316–86). Films of 0.5 mm thickness for testing were prepared by compression molding at a pressure of 27.5 MPa and at a temperature of 200 ◦C. To prevent sticking of materials to the molding plates, Teflon foil was used. All sample films were cut into a 10 cm diameter circle. The permeation analysis was done five time for each sample and the average value was taken for study. The comparative biodegradability of nanobiocomposites was studied in comparisons to copolymer and neat polymer in active sludge water for 180 days according to the ASTM standard (ASTM D5864 - 18). The activated sludge water was collected from tank areas receiving toilet and domestic waste water. The microorganisms like bacteria, fungi, yeast, etc. in the sludge water were responsible for the biodegradation of the materials.
Tensile bars were prepared using a Van Dorn 55 HPS 2.8F injection molding machine at a melt temperature of 190 ◦C, mold temperature of 40 ◦C, injection speed of 40 mm/s, holding pressure of 13.8 MPa, holding time of 20 s and cooling time of 20 s. The tensile property of nanobiocomposites was tested by the help of an Instron machine (Canton, MA, USA) of crossed-head speed of 1.5 mm/min having ASTM D638. Kirby–Bauer assay [51] was used to evaluate the antimicrobial properties of PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites against four different bacterial strains such as E. coli, P. aeruginosa, S. aureus and B. subtilis. Agar plates with nutrient broth were continuously shaken for 24 h at 30 ◦C for preparation of bacterial culture with 200 rpm. The dispersion of nanobiocomposites was prepared using tetra hydro furan (THF) and dimethyl formamide (DMF). Whatman filter paper discs of 6 mm size were supplied with 100 µL of nanobiocomposites dispersion and subjected to 24 h incubation. The zone of inhibition was recorded after the completion of incubation period.

sections.heading: 4.1. Spectroscopic analysis
sections.text:
UV–visible spectroscopy is used to confirm the formation of metallic nanoparticles due to their characteristic surface Plasmon
Scheme 1. Schematic representation for preparation of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites.
resonance spectra. Various factors like dielectric medium, surface adsorbed species, size of nanoparticles and chemical surroundings are accountable for the nature of surface plasmon peak of nanoparticles [52,53]. The UV–visible spectra of various wt% of silver nanoparticles were recorded in Fig. 1(a). The characteristic surface Plasmon peak of AgNPs were found 416 nm, 419 nm, 427 nm and 430 nm for.5 wt%, 1wt%, 1.5wt% and 2wt% of AgNPs respectively. The peak broadening was occurred with increase in wt% of AgNPs. The peak broadening is noticed with increase in wt% AgNPs [54]. The red shift of peaks with increase in wt% of AgNPs is also in agreement with increase in particle size and poly-dispersity of nanoparticles [55].
Fourier-Transform infrared spectroscopic studies are done in order to investigate the presence of interactions during the formation of composites. The FTIR spectra of PEMA-co-starch, PEMAco-starch/GO, PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag.5wt% and PEMA-co-starch/ GO/Ag2wt% are given in Fig. 1(b). The Fig. 1(c) and (d) have shown the FTIR spectra of GO and starch respectively. The FTIR spectra of starch has peak at 3620 cm−1 due to OH stretching. Starch has FTIR peak at 3144 cm−1 which correspond to C–H stretching. starch also have peaks at 2143 cm−1. The peak at 1655 cm−1 corresponds to signal of absorbed water. The peak due to –CH2group appears at 1451 cm−1. The presence of spectra at 1170– 1072 cm−1 corresponds to C–H stretching and C–O bending. The peak at 1155 cm−1 indicates the presence of C–C & C–O stretching. The characteristic peak of OH stretching peak of GO is obtained at 3430 cm−1. The peak at 2960 cm−1 corresponds to C–H group and the peak at 1722 cm−1 is obtained due to C = O group of carbonyl group and carboxylic group. The peak at 1374 cm−1indicates the presence of C-OH group in GO. These are prime peaks which confirms the formation of GO [56]. The peak at
1078 cm−1 corresponds to C–O bond and that of C-O-C stretching is obtained at 1255 cm−1.
PEMA-co-starch has peaks at 2960 cm−1 is due to C–H stretching of PEMA. The peak at 1722 cm −1 is due to –C = O stretching of carbonyl group, peaks from 1142 cm−1–1245 cm−1 are the –CO-C stretching peaks of PEMA. The –C-C-O asymmetric bending of PEMA is obtained at 744 cm−1. In PEMA-co-starch the –OH stretching peak of starch shifted from 3620 cm−1 to 3590 cm−1
which indicates the presence of intermolecular hydrogen bonding between PEMA and starch [57]. Here the intensity of –OH peak decreases which implies the removal of OH group of starch due to gelation [57]. PEMA-co-starch/GO has peaks at 3435 cm−1 due to –OH stretching. This right shifting of –OH peak of PEMA-costarch/GO than that of the copolymer indicate the interaction of copolymer with GO and it is also due to the existence of hydrogen bonding [58]. The peak at 1720 cm−1 due to –C = O stretching and that of –C-O-C stretching of PEMA is obtained at 1142 cm−1. In PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag.5wt%, the OH stretching peaks is obtained at 3427 cm−1 (shifted to lesser wave number region than PEMA-co-starch/GO) which is due to existence of some interaction between hydroxyl group and AgNPs [59]. Bao et al. [59] synthesized AgNPs/GO composites for water disinfection where presence of interaction between AgNPs and GO is responsible for the shifting of –OH peak to lesser wave number region. The peak at 2362 cm−1 is due to C–H stretching of PEMA. The peaks at 1720 cm−1 and 1142 cm−1 are due to –C = O stretching, –CO-C stretching of PEMA. In PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag2wt% only the intensity of OH stretching peaks is slightly increased along with the presence of other peaks.

sections.heading: 4.2. Structural characterization
sections.text:
The XRD plots of GO, AgNPs, Starch, PEMA-co-starch, PEMAco-starch/GO and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites are shown in Fig. 2. The XRD pattern of AgNPs has shown the peaks at 2θ values 37.96◦, 44.11◦, 64.22◦ and 77.41◦. The diffraction peaks of AgNPs correspond to (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0) and (3 1 1) crystalline plane and face-centered cubic geometry. The crystallite size and d-spacing values of AgNPs are calculated using Debye– Scherrer equation. The d-spacing and crystallite size values are given as inset table in respective XRD plots of Fig. 3. From these data the interlayer spacing among GO platelets is found to be 3.06 nm having a 2θ peak at 14.57◦ [60]. The PEMA-co-starch copolymer contains the peaks PEMA along with the appearance of a new peak at 31.59◦. However, the peaks of starch are disappeared in copolymer which may attribute to the partial gelation of starch [57]. The disappearance of peak of GO in PEMA-costarch/GO is ascribed to the complete exfoliation of GO. Peprnicek et al. [61] mention complete exfoliation of clay in Polyvinyl chloride/clay composites is due to the disappearance of clay peak. The average crystallite size of AgNPs.5wt% is found to be 10.57 nm as measured from XRD spectra. The XRD peaks of AgNPs are also present in PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag.5wt% nanobiocomposite. The average size of AgNPs.5wt% in composite is calculated and found to be 8.28 nm.
The morphology of the PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposite is analyzed from SEM images as shown in Fig. 3. The SEM images of the PEMA-co-starch and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposite are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3c shows the SEM image of PEMA-co-starch. The spherical geometry of PEMA is slightly distorted due to its copolymerization with starch. The SEM image of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag.5wt% nanobiocomposite is shown in Fig. 3d which indicates the formation of copolymer over GO flakes. The image also shows the uniform scattering of GO platelets over copolymer matrix. The distinct presence of AgNPs in bionanocomposites is not visible in SEM images due to their successful structural integration with GO sheets and copolymer matrix.
The presence of silver nanoparticles is not distinguished in SEM image but EDXS analysis confirms the presence of AgNPs in PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag.5wt% nanobiocomposite. The EDXS analysis of copolymer and nanobiocomposite are shown in Fig. 3a & b. From the results it is clear that EDXS of copolymer do not have peak of silver whereas that of nanobiocomposite have the peak of silver. The weight% of AgNPs is found to be 0.51. The TEM images of PEMA-co-starch/GO and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites are presented in Fig. 4. The GO platelets are clearly indicated in the TEM image of PEMA-co-starch/GO (Fig. 4a). The presence of silver nanoparticles in nanobiocomposites is clearly indicated from TEM images of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag2wt% in
Fig. 4b & c. These particles have irregular spherical morphology and average sizes within the range of 30 nm for PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag2wt%. The SEAD pattern of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposite is shown in Fig. 4d. The SEAD pattern of composite indicates the presence of some crystalline structure in nanobiocomposites. The TEM images of AgNPs are shown in Fig. 4e & f. It is found that the structure of Ag NPs is approximately spherical with average diameter of 30 nm.

sections.heading: 5.1. Biodegradation & thermal stability study
sections.text:
The biodegradability studies of PEMA-co-starch, PEMA-costarch/GO, PEMA-co-starch/GO /Ag nanocomposite are done with an interval of 30 days for six months which is given in Fig. 5(a).
The non-biodegradable polymer PEMA has shown biodegradability in copolymer due to incorporation of starch during the formation of composites. This may be due to the complete dispersion of starch within PEMA matrix. However, the incorporation of GO and AgNPs has reduced the biodegradability of PEMA-co-starch. The biodegradability of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposite with 2wt% AgNPs loading is 4.5% after six months. However, the biodegradability of copolymer (PEMA-co-starch) is more than 5% (Starch content) after 180 days. Further, the biodegradability of composites increases with increase in time duration. But, the biodegradability slightly hampers due to addition of GO and AgNPs. Similar types of outcomes in biodegradable poly (butylene succinate)/graphene oxide nanobiocomposites and biodegradable Polyester/functionalized graphene oxide nanobiocomposites are also reported by Wang et al. [62] and Hazarika et al. [63] respectively. The FTIR of sludge water treated PEMA and biodegraded PEMA-co-starch, PEMA-co-starch/GO and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites samples are shown in Fig. 5(c). The presence of characteristic -OH peak of starch in PEMA-co-starch, PEMA-co-starch/GO and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites suggests the further biodegradability of the materials even after 180 days.
The thermogravimetric analysis studies are recorded to determine the thermal stability of synthesized composite materials. The TGA studies of PEMA, starch, GO, PEMA-co-starch, PEMA-costarch/GO and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag are given in Fig. 5(b) three stage thermal degradation pattern is observed for PEMA. The degradation at 100 ◦C is due to removal of water vapor. The next degradation occurs at 290 ◦C which is mainly due to structural deformation of PEMA followed by third stage degradation at
370 ◦C where the oxidation of partial decomposed PEMA takes place [64]. The thermal degradation of GO in the range of 220 ◦C–290 ◦C corresponds to removal of labile oxygen functional groups present in GO [65]. The decomposition of carbonaceous structure is occurred after 500 ◦C [66]. GO has nearly 48% residue after 800 ◦C. The thermal decomposition of PEMA-co-starch/GO starts from 252 ◦C while that of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag starts from 266 ◦C. About 21% residue is obtained after 500 ◦C for PEMA-co-starch/GO and 24% for PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag1.5wt%. The second and third degradation temperatures for PEMA-costarch/GO are 288 ◦C and 378 ◦C. The second and third degradation temperatures for PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag are 305 ◦C and 392 ◦C respectively. There is no residue in case of PEMA, starch and PEMA-co-starch respectively.

sections.heading: 5.2. Oxygen barrier & chemical resistance study
sections.text:
Highly oxygen barrier polymer-based materials are suitable for packaging industries. The Oxygen permeability of PEMA-costarch, PEMA-co-starch/GO and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites of different weight percentage of nano silver were taken at variable pressure as well as at constant pressure (Fig. 6(a) & (b)). The oxygen permeability of PEMA-co-starch/GO was less in comparison to copolymer. The high barrier property of GO is responsible for considerable reduction in oxygen permeability of copolymer with incorporation of GO [67]. Wu et al. [67] reported the nano barrier activity of larger lateral size GO nano sheets in poly (lacticacid)/nano graphene oxide@starch composites which further indicates the compatibility between poly (lactic acid) and nano graphene oxide@starch. The oxygen permeability
further decreases with incorporation of nano silver. Similar behavior is obtained for both oxygen permeability study at constant pressure and variable pressure represented in Fig. 6a & b. The chemical resistance of both acid and alkali resistance of PEMA-costarch, PEMA-co-starch/GO, PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag.5wt%, PEMAco-starch/GO/Ag1wt%, PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag1.5wt%, PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag2wt% composites are studied for 180 days with an interval of 30 days (Fig. 6(c) & (d)). Both the acid and alkali resistance of copolymer increases with GO loading. Further enhancement in chemical resistance increase with increase in nano silver percentage. Uniform dispersion of both GO and AgNPs throughout the copolymer matrix is the main reason for this [68]. The weight loss of synthesized composites is little bit more in alkali in comparison to acid.

sections.heading: 5.3. Tensile properties
sections.text: The graph between tensile strength and nano silver content is shown in Fig. 7. The tensile strength of PEMA-co-Starch/GO is found to be 62.3 MPa. The tensile properties of PEMA-coStarch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites have increased with increasing AgNPs content. The increase in tensile property confirms the presence of interaction between AgNPs with GO and copolymeric matrix. A sudden rise in tensile strength is observed from 0.5wt% to 1wt% of AgNPs loading after this it is slowly rises. The experimental curve is fitted with tripolymeric regression curve and the R2 value is found to be 0.9929. Similar result is obtained by Jin et al. [69].

sections.heading: 5.4. Antibacterial activity study
sections.text:
There is the existence of microorganism almost everywhere (ocean, air and soil) in the environment. The microbes are responsible for number of serious diseases and severe hygienic issues particularly in food industry. Microbes are also responsible for medical-device associated infections [67,70–72]. Thus antimicrobial materials are very essential for fighting microorganisms but the conventional antibiotics are not effective for killing antibioticresistant bacteria (examples, Staphylococcus aureus and Neisseria gonorrhoeae have resistance towards benzyl penicillin) [73,74]. The requirement arises for the improvement of new generation antimicrobial material. AgNPs have antimicrobial activity against a wide range of microbes [75] and the antimicrobial efficacy of GO is also reported in literature [38]. As a biocide AgNPs is even more effective in comparisons to tetracycline, penicillin etc [73]. The combined antimicrobial activity will helpful in making PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag composite as an effective antimicrobial material.
Although the mechanism behind the antimicrobial activity of AgNPs is uncertain, the possible mechanism are (i) the electrostatic interaction between negative charge of cell membrane and positive charge of Ag+ ion. The Ag+ ion also have the capacity of destroying bacterial DNA replication process by the development of strong interaction with –SH group of essential enzymes [70,76]. (ii) The formation of reactive oxygen species also responsible for the antimicrobial activity of AgNPs [77]. Different factors like
size and distribution are also responsible for the antimicrobial efficacy of AgNPs [75]. Since the particles with small size have the tendency (to minimize surface energy) to agglomerate resulting in decrease of surface area. In order to avoid this proper support
material should be required [78]. GO has planar structure with a number of functionalities like –COOH, -OH and >C = O along with have low cytotoxicity and large surface area [79]. Thus GO will serve as a suitable candidate for supporting the AgNPs.
PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites powder of 10 mg quantity is added to the 10 mL (5 mL THF + 5 mL DMF) of solvent then subjected to sonication for proper dispersion. Filter papers disc of 6 mm size are placed in nutrient agar disc followed by the addition of 100 µL of dispersed solution of PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites to the filter paper disc. The antimicrobial activities of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites with different wt% of AgNPs are provided in Fig. 8. The antimicrobial activity of solvent in each bacteria is provided in image O. The respective antimicrobial activities of PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag.5wt%, PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag1wt%, PEMA-costarch/GO/Ag 1.5wt% and PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag2wt% nanobiocomposites are cited in image A, B, C and D plates. Table 1 has the value of antimicrobial activity of nanobiocomposites. A gradual increasing trend of antimicrobial property is noticed in PEMAco-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites with increasing wt% of AgNPs. Homogeneous distribution of GO and AgNPs over copolymer matrix is the key factor responsible for antimicrobial activity of nanobiocomposites. The increase in size of AgNPs is the main factor for the increasing trend of antimicrobial activity of nanobiocomposites [80].

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text:
The PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag nanobiocomposites are prepared by low cost green technique with in situ polymerization method. The synthesized nanobiocomposites are characterized by UV– visible, FTIR, XRD, SEM and TEM. The thermal stability of prepared nanobiocomposites is improved with a residual mass of 24% left with silver loading of 1.5 wt%. The usefulness of PEMA in packaging industry is reported in literature but the enhanced properties of PEMA-co-starch/GO/Ag have made it more eyecatching for packaging industry. The degradation temperature of
material increases with a remaining residue of 24% after 800 ◦C. The oxygen barrier property is increased by 40% in PEMAco-starch/GO/Ag2wt%. The chemical resistance properties have also increased. The biodegradability of nanobiocomposites is 4.5% after 180 days. The nanobiocomposites with improved thermal and gas barrier properties along with biodegradable, chemical resistance and antimicrobial behavior make the materials suitable for potential packaging applications
